inlineContent.text: Contributed 7 session notes in total. Their most active year was 2020.

abstract.text: Put on your detective’s hat: It’s time to track down those unruly app terminations. We’ll outline the six major reasons apps terminate in the background, and show you how you can use MetricKit to to help you identify key statistics to drive down the rate of terminations. Learn how to prevent problems and recover gracefully from inevitable jetsams, identify any underlying issues, and take actionable measures to fix them. And discover the importance of implementing state restoration to make terminations less jarring — especially where text entry or playback is concerned.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Why is my app getting killed?

abstract.text: Get the test results that matter — and skip the ones that don’t. Discover how you can implement XCTSkip to conditionally avoid tests at runtime. We’ll take you through how to return this new test result and better document tests beyond pass and fail within your test bundle.
Take a deeper dive into the new tools, technologies, and advances across Apple platforms that will help you create even better apps.

Meet WidgetKit: the best way to bring your app’s most useful information directly to the home screen. We’ll show you what makes a great widget and take a look at WidgetKit’s features and functionality. Learn how to get started creating a widget, and find out how WidgetKit leverages the power of SwiftUI to provide a stateless experience. Discover how to harness your existing proactive technologies to make sure your widget surfaces relevant material. And create a Timeline that ensures your content is always fresh.
Session notes shared by the community for the community.

The Apple Worldwide Developers Conference kicks off with exciting reveals, inspiration, and new opportunities to continue creating the most innovative apps in the world. Join the worldwide developer community for an in-depth look at the future of Apple platforms, directly from Apple Park.
WWDCNotes is only possible thanks to these awesome volunteers! Contribute now to get listed here as well.

The Xcode Library is an easy way for you to discover available SwiftUI views and drag and drop them to the Xcode Previews canvas, enabling rich visual editing of your app. We’ll show you how to extend the content of the Xcode Library with your own views and modifiers, optimizing for reusability and discoverability within your app or Swift packages.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Add custom views and modifiers to the Xcode Library
